displayName: "Rebels and Revels: Part One" - Pivotal Fragment

parameters: \pop[2]I sit in my chair, the gummies slowly kicking in.
\pop[2]There's a character sheet in front of me, and a map on the table.
\pop[2]It looks like some sort of fantasy village, settled in a forest.
\pop[2]Everything is a bit foggy right now, but I'm super content and relaxed.
\pop[2]Taylor, behind some sort of cardboard barrier, starts to speak.
\pop[2]I guess it's his time to shine. His first game is a GM.
The sheltered forest village of Valinorth.
The war has ended, and The Monarch returns home.
\pop[2]Everyone looks at me, and I nod.
\pop[2]I didn't know I'd be the main character in this game, to be honest.
\pop[2]But it kind of feels nice, so I accept the role without any hesitation.
\pop[5]You're here to visit your friend, The Elder of Valinorth.
Disguised as Monarch business, you really just want to see a friend.
The crown weighs heavy upon you, and your bonds ease this burden.
\pop[2]Everyone looks at Klace. He seems a little shocked.
The Monarch appointed you as Elder, because of your values.
You wished to see Valinorth open up, and unite with other nations.
Honestly, the world could use more of that.
\pop[5]Spoken like a true Elder, but also a little off topic.
The Monarch's bodyguard steps forward, aiming to get back on track.
\pop[2]Taylor taps the tablet, getting Kyron's attention.
\pop[2]I didn't know that Taylor made up backstories for our characters.
\pop[2]Signing up as just a sword-user, I figured my history would be a clean slate.
\pop[2]But a Monarch? With a bodyguard? I could get used to this.
\pop[3]Let's get this back on track, shall we?
The war may be over, but that doesn't mean it's playtime.
\pop[5]As if to urge on small talk, another friend steps forward.
Once a swindler, it seemed like he still craved gossip.
\pop[2]Everyone looks over at Isaac, who simply shrugs.
\pop[4]A swindler...? Come on, that's kinda mean.
I thought you saw me as more than that.
\pop[2]Isaac quickly realizes there's no way to address this in character.
\pop[2]With a simple shrug, he continues on from Taylor's earlier prompt.
\pop[4]Hey, there's nothing wrong with some small talk, Kyron.
A lot of people spill their greatest secrets in casual conversation.
\pop[3]What secrets could he \c[14]possibly\c[0] be keeping from us?
\pop[4]Yeah. I'm more interested in whatever the \c[14]opposite\c[0] of that is.
\pop[5]You mean obedience? I like that in a guy.
\pop[2]He's trying to flirt, even as the GM...?
\pop[3]Other than us? Can't say I have.
\pop[4]Maybe it was a whisper from the spirits...
\pop[5]Either way, the spirits don't work like that in this world.
In fact, the end of the war marked the end of the spirit realm.
Alestia was free to forge its own path, with no external influence.
\pop[4]No external influence? Funny for a GM to say.
\pop[4]Oh, how I hate those gods that look down upon us.
Cursing my existence to that of a lowly swindler.
\pop[4]For the record, I think being a swindler is pretty awesome.
I fight henchman, while you topple nations.
\pop[3]Yeah, and you totally look the part.
I wonder if anyone will get it.
\pop[5]It's not like there's anyone watching us.
So why are we here again, anyway?
Didn't we have some Monarch business to attend to?
\pop[2]Everyone exchanges glances, then stares right at Taylor.
\pop[2]Taylor nudges his head toward Dante, as if this were a cue.
\pop[2]Dante holds up a piece of paper, a mock scroll.
\pop[5]And at that exact moment, The Monarch's advisor bursts into the room.
Holding a scroll, and struggling to catch his breath, it seems urgent.
\pop[3]I am \c[14]not\c[0] acting like I'm out of breath.
Just go ahead and read the scroll.
We need to get this show on the road.
\pop[3]Right, right. Sorry to disturb your "small talk", Monarch.
But I have a matter that might need your attention.
And I was talking to The Monarch, not you.
\pop[4]When you're in my village, you talk to \c[14]me\c[0].
Let's not start disrespecting my authority, here.
\pop[2]Everyone looks at each other, shocked that Klace put his foot down.
\pop[2]I guess he was getting into the role. That made things even better.
\pop[4]Thank you, Dante. But now you have to prove that apology.
A sorry means nothing if you keep slipping up.
Should I get that in writing, and make you sign it?
Binding people to their word is kinda my thing.
\pop[4]That's why I live my life by \c[14]one\c[0] rule.
It's impossible to strike on the promise of a "maybe".
Well, if you don't find \c[14]me\c[0] reliable, then have this.
It's a letter from The Thorns, back in Mazeo.
\pop[5]Well, I guess everyone says it differently.
Anyway, feel free to let them know what's happening.
The voice from above seems to keep cutting me off.
But go ahead and lay it on us, Dante.
Can't possibly be worse than the war.
\pop[3]Maybe not. But it could easily start another.
The war definitely left a big power vacuum - we have to face that fact.
Unfortunately, a power vacuum in Mazeo is a lot worse than anywhere else.
\pop[3]Yeah. I figured you'd be familiar with them.
They're using the confusion and chaos to make a move.
It's pretty clear. They want to undermine our newfound leadership.
\pop[4]And let me guess - their main weapon is blackmail.
\pop[3]Of course. After you stopped swindling, they took charge.
Or maybe they even started during the war, when you were busy.
But the townspeople are in their hands. Not willingly, of course.
\pop[4]We should take care of this as soon as possible.
A hostile Mazeo isn't exactly my idea of a good neighbour.
\pop[4]Contrary to popular belief, paper \c[14]does\c[0] beat paper.
We dig up dirt on them, and ruin their credibility.
Then the "blackmail" they have means nothing.
\pop[4]I don't think that's a good idea.
We have to prove our leadership to those still on the fence.
Subterfuge and shady stuff will only make us seem dubious.
\pop[3]I agree. Our goal was to lead the world into a better age.
We can't resort to the same tactics our enemies did.
Or even the ones we used in order to win the war.
That kind of stuff would stop after we won.
We're leading now, so we have to do it \c[14]right\c[0].
\pop[4]Fine, fine. Old habits die hard, I guess.
It'll just be hard to win a battle where our enemy fights dirty.
Remember, we were a little dirty during the war. That's how we won.
\pop[4]But this is just some gang of information brokers.
They'll live up to their name. Nothing more than thorns in our sides.
They can't hold a candle to The Triumvirate, right? The worst is over.
\pop[3]And if it isn't, then you'll always have my sword arm.
In fact, I expect an ambush or two on our way back home.
We should head to Mazeo while it's still bright outside.
\pop[3]I agree. I made good time on the run over, too.
If we leave now, we'll make it before it gets too dark.
And that's just when The Thorns are most likely to strike.
\pop[5]And with that, our merry gang is reunited once more.
Fresh off the heels of one war, it seems they aimed to prevent another.
They head out, hoping to win this battle the right way, and prove their mettle.
\pop[5]Because even though the previous tyrannical leaders were dethroned?
The people of Alestia hadn't fully embraced their new leaders.
If things went awry, the New Monarchy could very well be usurped.
\pop[5]After a long and arduous journey, the group returns to Mazeo.
A meeting is immediately called, with everyone making their way to the war room.
Feeling no need to change things up, the New Monarchy still used the old Rebel HQ.
\pop[3]So, do we want to go over all of this again?
\pop[4]Yeah. It looks like The Thorns want to run things around here.
Apparently, they've dug up dirt on us. A lot.
If they spread it, the people could fear us.
\pop[3]Giving them a legitimate claim to leadership...
\pop[4]There's no way the people would side with The Thorns.
Leaking secrets speaks more about \c[14]them\c[0] than us.
It's a pitiful, destructive way to seize power.
\pop[4]Don't forget what my job used to be, Klace.
But you did that stuff out of necessity.
It seems like they're just doing it for fun.
\pop[2]It seems like the tables have turned, actually.
\pop[2]We dug up dirt on The Triumvirate, and used it to take them down.
\pop[2]I suppose it's not out of the question that someone would do the same to us.
\pop[2]But on the other hand, what we did actually saved countless worlds.
\pop[2]The Thorns just want to take advantage of something that could profit them.
\pop[2]We acted in the name of the greater good, and it seems like they act for their coinpurse.
\pop[3]Well, I think this one rests with Isaac.
How could we fight back against this...?
It \c[14]is\c[0] your area of expertise, after all.
\pop[4]Well, we have to put the people first.
Anything aggressive or manipulative is a no-go.
The way we react now, will decide how they see us.
The Thorns could have dirt on every citizen in Alestia.
If we take them out, and seize their base, it'd keep everyone save.
\pop[3]I think it's just \c[14]killing\c[0] that we need to avoid.
We can attack them, and take them in.
\pop[3]It would work. That is, if they truly \c[14]are\c[0] a threat.
We can't just take them down to save our own hide.
Isaac, you know more about this than anyone else.
Forget about whatever dirt they have on us.
I'm talking about how they could harm our people.
\pop[4]Yeah, information brokering is a shady business.
They probably have secrets that could topple nations.
And a lot more that could tear apart the lives of innocents.
\pop[4]But they would argue that revealing the truth \c[14]is\c[0] justice.
I even told myself that when we fought against The Triumvirate.
A means to an end. Everything is always a means to an end.
\pop[4]Remember how you'd dig in mailboxes at the taverns?
You know, to find out secrets you could sell?
\pop[4]Well, that's not all you did, right?
I imagine you \c[14]bought\c[0] information from people, too.
What if we posed as civilians looking to sell some info?
But a way to get into their base for recon.
That way we could see what they're up to, in every regard.
\pop[3]And crack down if we see anything worrying...
But I don't see anything that would reflect poorly on us.
We'll only take them down if we see the potential of harming our people.
\pop[3]Well, I know that we did a \c[14]lot\c[0] to take down The Triumvirate.
We swindled nations, and murdered our enemies, to start the list.
If The Thorns bring that to light, we'll have to accept the repercussions.
\pop[3]Well, it really isn't right to try and cover up our actions.
Especially if it means hiding the truth of things from our people.
That's exactly what The Triumvirate did to us when it came to the spirits.
\pop[3]They hid a truth that that \c[14]knew\c[0] would jeopardize their leadership.
If we approach this from the same angle, then we're no better.
We have to act in Alestia's best interests. Not our own.
Infiltrate their base, and gather data?
\pop[3]And we only take action if we believe our people are in danger.
With what Isaac said though, I'm almost certain that they are.
We just need to prove it before cracking down on them.
\pop[2]For a moment, I forgot I was taking part in this game.
\pop[2]But in retrospect, it really did make me feel like I was the leader.
\pop[2]Everyone talking about what to do, before presenting me with their best option.
\pop[2]But it really was the best option.
\pop[2]We can't just attack and kill those who threaten our rule.
\pop[2]But if the actions of The Thorns threaten our people? That's different.
\pop[2]We'd infiltrate their base, and discern the full extent of their actions.
\pop[2]I know Isaac says they're obviously a threat, but we need some evidence.
\pop[2]We'd have to do this the right way, in order to win the favor of our people.
\pop[2]It's not an easy transition, waking up to new rulers of the world, after all.
\pop[2]But we'd show them, as we continued, that their lives were in our capable hands.
